coredata.dc:title: Three-dimensional polyimide nanofiber framework reinforced polymer electrolyte for all-solid-state lithium metal battery
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science

Zhang, Wenkui
coredata.dc:description: The replacement of traditional liquid electrolytes with polyethylene oxide (PEO) based composite polymer electrolytes (CPEs) is an important strategy to address the current flammability and explosiveness of lithium batteries since PEO CPEs have high flexibility, excellent processability and moderate cost. However, the insufficient ionic conductivity and inferior mechanical strength of PEO CPEs do not suit the operating requirements of all-solid-state lithium metal batteries at room temperature. Herein, three-dimensional (3D) framework composed of interweaved high-modulus polyimide (PI) nanofibers along with functional succinonitrile (SN) plasticizers are employed to synergistically reinforce the ionic conductivity and mechanical strength of PEO CPEs. Impressively, benefitting from the synergistic effects of 3D PI framework and SN plasticizer, PI-PEO-SN CPEs exhibits high ionic conductivity of 1.03 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 30 °C, remarkable tensile strength of 4.52 MPa, and superior Li dendrites blocking ability (>400 h at 0.1 mA cm−2). Such favorable features of PI-PEO-SN CPEs endow LiFePO4/PI-PEO-SN/Li solid-state prototype cells with high specific capacity (151.2 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C), long cycling lifespan (>150 cycles with 91.7 % capacity retention), and superior operating safety even under bending, folding and cutting harsh conditions. This work will pave the avenues to design and fabricate new high-performance PEO CPEs for the high energy density and safety all-solid-state batteries.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Synthetic schematic of PI reinforced PEO/LiTFSI/SN CPEs.
(a-b) Digital images of PI films. SEM images of (c) 3D PI nanofiber framework, (d) PI-PEO-SN film, and (e-f) PI-PEO-SN film, respectively.

(a) XRD patterns of various CPEs films and raw materials. (b) DSC curves of various CPEs films. (c) Mechanical tensile stress–strain curves of various CPEs films. (d) Digital images of PI-PEO-SN film and PP separator at different temperatures. (e) TGA curves of PI-PEO-SN and PEO-SN films.

(a) Nyquist plots of PI-PEO-SN film, where R 0 and Z w represent Ohmic resistance and Warburg impedance, respectively. (b) Arrhenius plots of the Li+ conductivity of CPEs. (c) Linear sweep voltammograms of CPEs at 30 °C. (d) Chronoamperometry curve of PI-PEO-SN film at a potential step of 10 mV at 30 °C. Inset is impedance spectra before/after polarization.

(a-b) Cycling stability comparison of Li symmetrical cells assembled with CPEs under different current densities of 0.05 and 0.1 mA cm−2 with a capacity of 0.05 and 0.1 mA h cm−2 at 30 °C. (c-d) Surface SEM images of cycled Li anodes paired with PEO-SN and PI-PEO-SN. (e) Schematic diagram of lithium deposition behavior of PEO-SN and PI-PEO-SN.

(a) Rate performance comparison of LFP/CPEs/Li cells at 30 °C. (b) Long-term cycling performance and Coulombic efficiency of LFP/CPEs/Li cells at 0.2 C and 30 °C. (c) Charge-discharge curves of different cycles obtained from LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li cells at 0.2 C and 30 °C. (d) Charge-discharge curves of LFP/PEO-SN/Li cells at the 82nd and 99th cycles. (e) The EIS results of LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li cells before and after cycling at 0.2 C. (f) Long-term cycling performance and Coulombic efficiency of LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li cells at 0.5 C and 1.0 C at 30 °C.

(a) Open circuit voltage (OCV) test of a typical LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li pouch cell. Optical photos of LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li pouch cell for the safety tests at various states: (b) flat, (c) bending, (d) folding, and (e) cutting, respectively.

head.ce:title: Three-dimensional polyimide nanofiber framework reinforced polymer electrolyte for all-solid-state lithium metal battery

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: These authors contributed equally to this work.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The replacement of traditional liquid electrolytes with polyethylene oxide (PEO) based composite polymer electrolytes (CPEs) is an important strategy to address the current flammability and explosiveness of lithium batteries since PEO CPEs have high flexibility, excellent processability and moderate cost. However, the insufficient ionic conductivity and inferior mechanical strength of PEO CPEs do not suit the operating requirements of all-solid-state lithium metal batteries at room temperature. Herein, three-dimensional (3D) framework composed of interweaved high-modulus polyimide (PI) nanofibers along with functional succinonitrile (SN) plasticizers are employed to synergistically reinforce the ionic conductivity and mechanical strength of PEO CPEs. Impressively, benefitting from the synergistic effects of 3D PI framework and SN plasticizer, PI-PEO-SN CPEs exhibits high ionic conductivity of 1.03 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 30 °C, remarkable tensile strength of 4.52 MPa, and superior Li dendrites blocking ability (>400 h at 0.1 mA cm−2). Such favorable features of PI-PEO-SN CPEs endow LiFePO4/PI-PEO-SN/Li solid-state prototype cells with high specific capacity (151.2 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C), long cycling lifespan (>150 cycles with 91.7 % capacity retention), and superior operating safety even under bending, folding and cutting harsh conditions. This work will pave the avenues to design and fabricate new high-performance PEO CPEs for the high energy density and safety all-solid-state batteries.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: With the dramatic development of electric vehicles, energy storage equipment and electronic devices over the past few decades, the demand for high energy density storage systems is burgeoning. In the pursuit of higher energy densities, lithium metal batteries stand out among many energy storage systems due to the high theoretical capacity (3860 mA h g−1) and low potential (–3.04 V vs standard hydrogen electrode) of Li anodes [1–4]. However, the interfacial reaction between electrolyte and lithium anode leads to low Coulomb efficiency, uneven Li deposition, and even a spontaneous propensity to form continuous Li dendrites that pierce separators to trigger serious safety problems, which remain great challenges to strictly impede the commercialization of high energy density lithium metal batteries. In addition, organic electrolytes are prone to decomposition and combustion at high temperature, which severely limits the operating environment of lithium metal batteries [5–7].

To address these issues, solid-state electrolytes are considered to be the best alternative to liquid electrolytes and are generally classified into three categories: inorganic solid electrolytes (ISEs), solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs), and composite polymer electrolytes (CPEs) [8–10]. ISEs exhibit a satisfactory ionic conductivity (>10−3 S cm−1), which is even comparable to liquid electrolytes [11,12]. However, the inefficient transfer of ions and electrons between particles due to the hard “point-to-point” contact makes it difficult to fabricate working electrodes, as well as achieve high mass loading of electrode materials in large-scale practical applications [13–15]. SPEs possess the advantages of high softness, excellent processability, and good compatibility with electrodes [16,17]. Unfortunately, the low ionic conductivity of SPEs at room temperature and their inferior mechanical properties are not conducive to homogeneous lithium deposition, resulting serious Li dendrites growth [18,19]. In this regard, CPEs combined the merits of SPEs and ISEs not only have high flexibility and good formability, but also could provide considerable ionic conductivity and mechanical strength [20–23]. Therefore, CPEs are highly expected to be implemented in high energy density and safety all-solid-state lithium metal batteries [24,25].

Up to now, polyethylene oxide (PEO) based CPEs are widely studied because of their low manufacturing cost, high flexibility and stretchability, good processability, as well as moderate ionic conductivity [26]. However, the large-scale practical application of PEO based CPEs still faces two major challenges. One is the unsatisfactory ionic conductivity at room temperature (only 10−7 to 10−5 S cm−1). Another is the inferior intrinsic mechanical properties of PEO polymer matrix. In this aspect, great efforts are made to address these issues, such as introducing functional plasticizers [27,28], adding inorganic nanofillers [29–31], cross-linking [32], and blending [33], which have been verified to be beneficial to ameliorating the ionic conductivity and mechanical properties of PEO based CPEs. Particularly, succinonitrile (SN), a promising solid-state non-ionic plasticizer with an ordered lattice of molecules [34], is often added into PEO based electrolytes to inhibit the crystallization of PEO and to promote the dissolution of Li-salts, resulting for increasing the local ionic conductivity of CPEs [35–37]. Unfortunately, the addition of SN plasticizers also has negative effects, which will significantly sacrifice mechanical strength of CPEs. As a result, the insufficient mechanical strength of SN modified CPEs cannot suppress Li dendrites growth, and eventual lead to a short circuit in the batteries.

Recently, fruitful researches demonstrate that the introduction of three-dimensional (3D) frameworks as rigid supporting skeleton into CPEs could effectively enhance their mechanical strength under harsh conditions, such as pressing, bending or stretching [38]. Wu et al. [39] proposed a polyethylene (PE) separator reinforced PEO/LiTFSI CPEs. The robust PE provides an extra support for PEO/LiTFSI CPEs, thereby preventing short circuit even in the case of mechanical deformation. Moreover, Zhang et al. [40] reported a novel polyacrylonitrile/Li6.7La3Zr1.7Ta0.3O12 (PAN/LLZTO) nanofiber reinforced CPEs. The PAN/LLZTO nanofibers are uniformly dispersed in PEO-based matrix to create a continuous channel. The continuous channel not only promotes rapid Li+ transfer, but also enhances the mechanical strength of PEO CPEs and significantly inhibits Li dendrites growth. Such favorable features endow PAN/LLZTO nanofiber reinforced PEO based CPEs with satisfactory ionic conductivity and ultra-high electrochemical stability window, as well as high lithium-ion transfer number of 0.53. When PAN/LLZTO nanofibers reinforced PEO based CPEs are employed in LiFePO4/Li solid-state battery, it delivers a high discharge capacity of 120.7 mA h g−1 over 1000 cycles. Obviously, the introduction of supporting skeleton with rational tensile strength and yield strength could be effectively complementary to the mechanical strength and structure stability of PEO based CPEs.

In this work, we attempt to design and fabricate a series of high-performance PEO based CPEs composed of interwoven 3D polyimide (PI) frameworks as robust supporting skeleton and cost-effective SN as functional plasticizer, which is illustrated in Fig. 1 . The introduced 3D PI frameworks synthesized by electrostatic spinning will endow PEO based CPEs with greatly reinforced mechanical strength and enhanced interfacial stability since PI nanofibers not only have extremely high modulus to strengthen mechanical properties and Li dendrites blocking ability, leading to the enhanced operational safety, but also effectively reduce the crystallinity of PEO. Moreover, the added SN plasticizers can increase the solubility of lithium salts and inhibit PEO crystallization at the same time, thereby significantly promoting the ionic conductivity of CPEs. With the synergistic action of 3D PI frameworks and functional SN plasticizers, PI reinforced PEO/LiTFSI/SN CPEs exhibit high ionic conductivity of 1.03 × 10−4 S cm−1, large electrochemical window to 5.14 V, and remarkable tensile strength of 4.52 MPa at 30 °C, which are far superior to other counterparts. Consequently, the assembled all-solid-state LiFePO4/PI-PEO-SN/Li batteries deliver a high discharge capacity of 151.2 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C, excellent cycling stability (>150 cycles with 91.7 % capacity retention) with high Coulombic efficiency of > 99 %, and outstanding operational reliability even under various harsh conditions, such as bending, folding and cutting.

Polyethylene oxide (PEO, Mw = 600,000), succinonitrile (SN, 99 %), bis(trifluoromethane)sulfonimide lithium salt (LiTFSI, 99 %), acetonitrile (ACN, 99 %) were purchased from Aladdin. Polyamic acid solution (PAA, 13 wt%) was provided by Ningbo Boya Poly Advanced Materials Co., ltd. N, N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc, 99.8 %) and N-Methylpyrrolidone (NMP) were provided by Aladdin. To remove adsorbed moisture, LiFePO4 cathode materials (LFP, Shenzhen Dynanonic Co., ltd.) and conductive carbon black (Super-P, Shanghai Huipu Industrial Chemicals Co., ltd.) were dried in vacuum oven at 80 °C for 24 h before using.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation of polyimide nanofiber framework membrane
ce:section.ce:para: Polyimide (PI) nanofiber framework membrane was prepared via a conventional electrospinning method. In detail, a pristine spinning solution of 10 wt% PAA solution was prepared by dissolving PAA solution in DMAc solution with continuously stirring for 6 h to obtain a uniform precursor solution. After that, the as-prepared precursor solution was transferred to a syringe. The electrospinning spinning parameters were as follows: push rate, operating voltage and working distance between needle and roller collector were 0.6 ml h−1, 15 kV, and 10 cm, respectively.

The obtained PI nanofiber framework membrane was dried in vacuum oven at 80 °C for 6 h to remove the residual solvent completely. Then, the membrane was placed between two quartz glass plates for hot-pressing treatment to obtain PI nanofiber framework film under 350 °C for 30 min with an external force of 50 N.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation of PI based composite polymer electrolytes
ce:section.ce:para: PI based composite polymer electrolytes (PI-based CPEs) were fabricated by a facile solution casting method. Firstly, 1.000 g PEO, 0.541 g LiTFSI, 0.067 g SN were dissolved in 14.500 g ACN solution, and then vigorously stirred for 8 h to obtain a homogeneous PEO-SN solution. After that, the PEO-SN slurry was poured on PI nanofiber framework membranes and completely infiltrated onto the PI nanofiber framework film. Subsequently, the wet PI-based CPEs films were first dried in an argon atmosphere for 2 h. Afterwards, the obtained films were transferred into 55 °C vacuum oven to dry for 24 h to remove residual moisture and solvent, which were named as PI-PEO-SN. The simplified synthesis procedure of PI-PEO-SN CPEs is illustrated in Fig. 1. For comparison, PEO-SN slurry was coated onto a Teflon petri dish, and then dried in argon atmosphere for 2 h. Finally, the sample was transferred to a vacuum oven under 60 °C for 24 h to obtain PEO-SN electrolytes.
PEO-based electrolytes without SN were produced by the same procedure and without the addition of SN, which were named as PI-PEO and PEO, respectively.

LiFePO4 slurry was prepared by mixing LFP, PEO-SN electrolyte, and conductive carbon black with a weight ratio of 7:2:1 in NMP solution under vigorously stirring for 12 h. Then, the obtained LFP slurry was coated on a carbon-coated Al foil. Finally, LFP cathodes were dried in vacuum oven under 80 °C for 5 h. The mass loading of LFP active material on each working electrode was 1.5 mg cm−2.

Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) was performed on FEI Nova Nano 450 instrument equipped with an energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS, Oxford X-max 80) detector for the characterization of morphology and chemical composition. The phase and crystal structure were inspected by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku Ultima IV) in the 2θ ranging from 10° to 80°. The melting temperature of the CPEs samples was tested by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC, DSC Q1000) experiments from room temperature to 120 °C under a flowing nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted by using Q5000IR instrument from room temperature to 600 °C under a flowing nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The mechanical properties of samples were investigated by a dual column testing machine (Instron, 5966) with a stretching rate of 0.1 mm s−1.

The stainless steel (SS)/CPEs/SS symmetric cells were assembled to examined the ionic conductivity (σ) of various CPEs samples. The impedance frequency was changed from 10−1 Hz to 106 Hz by electrochemical workstation (Zahner PP211, Germany). Consequently, the values of σ were calculated using the equation (1):
(1)
σ =
L
R × S
where L is the thickness of CPEs samples, R is the resistance value, and S is the area of SS electrodes. The ionic transference number (t Li +) was examined by CHI660E electrochemical workstation (Chenhua, Shanghai, China) using Li/CPEs/Li cells. The polarization voltage was applied to 10 mV. t Li + was calculated based on equation (2):
(2)
t
Li +
=
I s
( Δ V -
I o
R o
)
I o
( Δ V -
I s
R s
)
where ΔV is the polarization voltage, I o and I s are the current before and after polarization, and Ro and R s are the resistance before and after polarization, respectively. The electrochemical window of PEO CPEs was measured by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) using SS/PEO CPEs/Li cells at a scanning rate of 1 mV s−1 from 1.5 V to 6 V on CHI660E electrochemical workstation. The interfacial electrochemical stability between Li anode and CPEs was investigated by monitoring the voltage variations of Li/CPEs/Li cells. Galvanostatic cycling experiments were carried out at 0.05 and 0.10 mA h cm−2 at 30 °C. The charge/discharge tests were carried out in the voltage ranging from 2.5 V to 3.8 V on Neware battery testing systems (BTS4000, China).

Fig. 1 depicts the preparation process of 3D PI framework-based CPEs. Firstly, 3D PI frameworks are prepared from PAA solutions by electrospinning method. PAA precursors are cross-linking at 300 °C to form a large-scale flexible 3D PI film with a uniform thickness of 25 µm as shown in Fig. 2 a-b. Subsequently, PEO-sN-LiTFSI solution is infiltrated into PI frameworks. After drying under vacuum at 60 °C for 24 h, PI-PEO-SN CPEs are obtained. Fig. 2c presents the morphology and microstructure of 3D PI frameworks, revealing vividly PI nanofibers with high aspect ratio are smooth and straight. The detailed diameter distribution of PI nanofibers is assessed in Figure S2 , which is ranging from 150 nm to 350 nm with an average diameter of ∼ 210 nm. It is worth noting that these slender PI nanofibers are tightly intertwined with each other to construct a robust 3D network architecture, which will endow CPEs with high mechanical strength due to the high modulus of PI. Moreover, as illustrated in Fig. 2d, the thickness of PI-PEO-SN film is ∼ 85 μm, which is similar to the counterpart of PI-PEO film with a thickness of ∼ 81 μm ( Fig. S3 b). However, PEO ( Fig. S3 a, thickness = ∼133 μm) and PEO-SN (Fig. S3c, thickness = ∼129 μm) samples are much thicker than PI-PEO-SN and PI-PEO samples supported by 3D PI frameworks. Usually, the thinner the CPE film is, the higher the ionic conductivity is. This is due to the short Li+ diffusion distance and time in CPEs, which could alleviate ohmic resistance, especially at high current densities[39]. Therefore, the reduction in the thickness of CPEs, without compromising the structural integrity of CPEs, enables the cells to deliver excellent electrochemical performance. In addition, abundant dense wrinkles can be observed on the surface of PEO film ( Fig. S3 d and g), corresponding to the local crystallization of PEO. In sharp contrast, after introducing SN, these wrinkles are significantly reduced in PEO-SN sample ( Fig. S3 f and i), suggesting the introduced SN could effectively decrease the crystallinity of PEO, which is more conducive to rapid Li+ transport and smooth surface. Furthermore, after incorporating PEO/LiTFSI and PEO/SN/LiTFSI solutions into 3D PI frameworks, the morphology of PI-PEO-SN and PI-PEO films is changed. As displayed in Fig. 2e-f, the surface of PI-PEO-SN film is flat and smooth without distinct wrinkles. However, there are many pores and microcracks in PI-PEO film ( Fig. S3 e and h), indicating PEO/LiTFSI solution can not completely infiltrate the 3D PI frameworks because of the inferior interfacial compatibility. This result suggests that the introduced SN can ameliorate the interfacial contact between PI frameworks and PEO/LiTFSI electrolyte, thereby reducing the interfacial impedance, as well as promoting the interfacial stability of PI-PEO-SN film with electrodes.

Generally, the high order crystallinity of PEO is not conducive to the fast Li+ conductivity [41,42]. Herein, the crystallinity of PI-PEO-SN and other CPEs are inspected by XRD. As shown in Fig. 3 a, two typical diffraction peaks are located at 19.3° and 23.4° in PEO powders. Consequently, PEO electrolyte film has the sharpest diffraction peaks among the other four samples. Impressively, after the introduction of 3D PI frameworks and SN, respectively, an increment in diffraction peak width can be clearly observed, implying the crystallinity of PEO is decreased in PI-PEO-SN, PI-PEO, and PEO-SN samples. Particularly, the diffraction peaks at 19.3° and 23.4° are disappeared from PI-PEO-SN sample. Meanwhile, there is only an amorphous peak in PI-PEO-SN sample, suggesting the synergistic effect of SN and PI framework greatly reduced the crystallinity of PEO, which is necessary for enhancing the Li+ migration ability in CPEs. In this respect, due to the high dispersion of PI nanofibers in PEO matrix, these PI nanofibers act as physical cross-linking points, which could greatly reduce the ordered arrangement and crystallization properties of PEO chains. Meanwhile, the SN plasticizers can increase the solubility of lithium salts and inhibit PEO crystallization. Additionally, this conclusion is also verified in DSC results. Fig. 3b clearly presents that the melting temperature (T m) of PEO electrolyte film is 54.1 °C. Whereas the heat absorption peaks of PI-PEO, PEO-SN, and PI-PEO-SN samples are shifted to 50.5 °C, 45.6 °C, and 39.7 °C, respectively, further confirming SN and PI synergistically reduce the crystallinity of PEO. It is worth mentioning that SN is a common plasticizer, which usually not only could reduce the crystallinity of PEO, but also cause a decrease in mechanical strength. As demonstrated in Fig. 3c, the tensile strength of PEO (0.44 MPa) is higher than PEO-SN (0.17 MPa). Fortunately, with the aid of high modulus 3D PI frameworks, the mechanical properties of PI-PEO and PI-PEO-SN samples are significantly improved to 5.17 MPa and 4.52 MPa, respectively, which are 30 times and 27 times that of PEO-SN sample. Apparently, this remarkable mechanical strength will effectively prevent the inevitable Li dendrite growth via PI-PEO-SN CPEs, thereby enhancing the safety of all-solid-state Li metal batteries.

Thermal stability is another important parameter for CPEs films [43,44]. In this work, we compare the thermal stability of PI-PEO-SN film and commercial polypropylene (PP) microporous separator (Celgard 2075), which are heated at various temperatures of 30 °C, 80 °C, 120 °C, and 180 °C for aging tests. As illustrated in Fig. 3d, the commercial PP separator is curling visibly at 80 °C. More seriously, PP separator has a conspicuous shrinkage when it is heated at 180 °C. Obviously, PP separator undergoes severe deformation during the aging tests, implying the dimensional stability is very poor that may trigger a severe threat to the safety of battery. On the contrary, PI-PEO-SN film still remains its initial shape without any detectable shrinkage even at 180 °C. In addition, as shown in Fig. 3e, when the temperature rises from is room temperature to 270 °C, a slight weight loss of 7 % could be detected in PI-PEO-SN and PEO-SN samples, which is due to the presence of absorbed moisture and SN. As the temperature is further increased to 385 °C, a conspicuous weight loss is occurred for PI-PEO-SN and PEO-SN samples, which is originated from the decomposition of PEO and LiTFSI. It is worth noting that there is no weight loss in PEO-SN sample after 450 °C, whereas the PI-PEO-SN sample still undergoes a slow weight loss. This phenomenon is mainly attributed to the adsorption effect of PI framework[41], which increases the sublimation energy of PEO and LiTFSI. Therefore, it is concluded that the CPEs introduced with PI framework have better thermal stability properties. These results clearly indicate that PI-PEO-SN film has superior thermal stability, which is beneficial for promoting battery safety at high-temperature applications.

The ionic conductivity depends on the electrolyte structure and ionic conduction mechanism. In general, Li+ ions are coordinated by the ether oxygen atoms on the segmental PEO chain[16]. The Li+ transport process is mainly dominated by the movement of amorphous chain segments, in which Li+ ions are continuously complexed and dissociated with the ether oxygen groups by repeatedly breaking/forming lithium-oxygen bonds to achieve Li+ transport in PEO-based electrolytes[18]. However, due to the high crystallinity of PEO, the movement of the chain segments is limited by the melting temperature (T m) of PEO. Fig. 4 a and Figure S4 display the Nyquist plots of PI-PEO-SN, PEO, PI-PEO, and PEO-SN films sandwiched between two stainless steel electrodes at temperature ranging from 30 °C to 60 °C. As summarized in Fig. 4b and Table S1 , the ionic conductivities of PI-PEO-SN and PEO-SN samples are 1.03 × 10−4 S cm−1 and 1.09 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 30 °C, which are much higher than that of PI-PEO (2.83 × 10−5 S cm−1) and PEO (3.54 × 10−5 S cm−1) samples. Additionally, when the temperature is raised to 60 °C, the ionic conductivities of PI-PEO-SN and PEO-SN samples significantly reach to 6.00 × 10−4 S cm−1 and 6.58 × 10−4 S cm−1, respectively. This result indicates that the introduced SN is responsible for the enhanced ionic conductivity of CPEs. Moreover, linear sweep voltammograms (LSV) are performed to verify the electrochemical window. As depicted in Fig. 4c, the introduced PI frameworks and SN significantly help to improve the electrochemical stability of CPEs. In this regard, the initial electrochemical oxidation potential of PI-PEO-SN film is as high as 5.14 V, which is much higher than other counterparts. Subsequently, the Li+ transfer number (t Li
+ ) is determined by DC polarization method as shown in Fig. 4d and Figure S5 . The EIS of PEO electrolyte decreases after polarization and the value of t Li + is 0.15. In contrast, the EIS of other CPEs increases after polarization, and the t Li + of PI-PEO-SN is calculated to be 0.38, which is higher than that of PI-PEO as well as PEO-SN, demonstrating that the t Li + is enhanced by the synergistic effects of PI and SN on reducing the crystallinity of PEO matrix in CPEs.

The growth of lithium dendrites is a major threat to the safety of rechargeable lithium metal battery [45,46]. The interface compatibility between lithium metal anode and CPEs is important to inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites during the repeated lithium plating and stripping process. Generally, the ability of CPEs to resistance to lithium dendrite growth is closely related to the mechanical strength of CPEs [47,48]. The Li symmetric cells are assembled to investigate the lithium dendrite inhibition behaviors and electrochemical compatibility (Fig. 5 a-b). In this work, after cycling at a current of 0.05 mA cm−2 for 180 h, the Li symmetric cell of PEO sample appears to short circuit due to its low ionic conductivity and inferior mechanical strength. Although the introduction of SN has greatly improved the ionic conductivity and allowed PEO-SN to have a lower polarization voltage compared to PEO sample, the insufficient mechanical property of PEO-SN results short circuit after long-term cycling of 400 h. In contrast, Li/PI-PEO-SN/Li cell can be cycled stably for 1000 h without short circuit. Moreover, PI-PEO-SN sample has a lower polarization voltage (0.18 V) than that of PI-PEO (0.60 V). Additionally, the Li symmetric cell employed with PI-PEO-SN is stable for 400 h even at a high current density of 0.1 mA cm−2, confirming that the introduced PI framework could effectively stabilize the interface between CPEs and Li anode, thereby inhibiting lithium dendrites.

To stand out the practical application feasibility of PI-PEO-SN CPEs in all-solid-state Li metal batteries, LFP/CPEs/Li coin cells are assembled to further the electrochemical performance. Fig. 6 a presents the multi-rate capability comparison of four samples in all-solid-state Li metal batteries. Impressively, LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li cell delivers remarkable specific discharge capacities of 160.8, 149.8, 137.1, 124.2, 84.3 mA h g−1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.5, and 1.0 C, respectively, along with a high and stable Coulombic efficiency of > 99 %. Moreover, as displayed in Figure S7 , a low charge and discharge polarization is clearly observed in LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li cell, revealing the superior Li+ diffusion ability of PI-PEO-SN CPEs. This significant improvement is also demonstrated by EIS results in Figure S8 . Notably, LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li cell exhibits the smallest semicircle, implying PI-PEO-SN CPEs could effectively reduce the interfacial charge transfer resistance due to the promoted ionic conductivity arising from the introduced SN. More importantly, the high ionic conductivity and low interfacial resistance is also favorable for the long-term cycling performance. As described in Fig. 6b, compared to the cells paired with PEO, PI-PEO, and PI-PEO-SN CPEs, LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li cell not only delivers a high initial specific discharge capacity of 151.2 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C, but also has a long cycle life, exceeding 150 cycles with a remarkable capacity retention of 91.7 %. Furthermore, with prolonging cycling numbers, no noticeable overpotential is existed in LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li cell after 150 cycles as presented in Fig. 6c, suggesting PI-PEO-SN CPEs are highly stable at the interfaces between LFP cathode and Li anode. Such auspicious feature indicates PI-PEO-SN CPEs have robust interfacial stability and excellent compatibility against Li dendrites, which is responsible for the superior cycling lifespan. On the contrary, although LFP/PEO-SN/Li cell delivers a high initial discharge capacity of 144.1 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C, a low Coulombic efficiency occurs at the 82nd cycle along with substantial jitters at the end of the subsequent charging curves (Fig. 6d), which is a symptom of battery short circuit [49,50]. Moreover, the EIS impedance of the LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li cell even becomes smaller after 150 cycles (Fig. 6e), indicating the interface compatibility is effectively improved during the cycling process. In sharp contrast, LFP/PEO-SN/Li cell eventually fails to operation at 99th cycle because of the savage growth of Li dendrites. These results clearly demonstrate that the insufficient mechanical strength of PEO-SN cannot resist the unceasing growth of Li dendrites, leading to the fragile interface between PEO-SN and Li anode. Analogously, the cell assembled by PEO CPEs also shows a short circuit at the 66th cycle ( Figure S9 ). Herein, it should be mentioned that although LFP/PI-PEO/Li cell has an unsatisfactory reversible discharge capacity of ∼ 87.6 mA h g−1, which mainly is due to the low ionic conductivity and large interfacial resistance, the cell still maintains a good Coulomb efficiency of ∼ 99 % and acceptable capacity retention of 87.2 % after 150 cycles. This is attributed to the high modulus PI frameworks that greatly enhance the mechanical strength of CPEs, thereby preventing effectively the Li dendrites growth. Furthermore, the long-term cycling performance of PI-PEO-SN at high current density is displayed in Fig. 6f. Even at 0.5 C and 1.0 C, the LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li cell still exhibit excellent cycle stability. To be more specific, the LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li cell delivers the acceptable initial discharge capacities of 115.8 mA h g−1 and 74.2 mA h g−1 at 0.5 C and 1.0 C, respectively. After 100 cycles, the reversable capacities of LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li cell are 102.6 mA h g−1 and 66.1 mA h g−1 with satisfactory capacity retentions of 88.6 % and 86.4 % at 0.5 C and 1.0 C, respectively. As shown in Table S2 , it is clear that the electrochemical performance of the LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li cell is better than the recently reported CPEs. On the basis of the above analyses, the superior electrochemical performance of LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li cell is mainly attributed to the synergistic effect of PI frameworks and SN plasticizers. On the one hand, SN plasticizers help CPEs to promote the ionic conductivity and interfacial compatibility, resulting the significantly reduced interfacial resistance. On the other hand, 3D PI frameworks play an important role in reinforcing the mechanical strength of CPEs, which is benefiting to achieve the highly reliable interface between CPEs and Li anodes, consequently preventing Li dendrites growth.

Additionally, to better identify the validity of PI-PEO-SN CPEs in the large-scale practical implementation, LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li pouch cell with a design capacity of 100 mA h is assembled to test the electrochemical performance. As shown in Figure S10 , the initial capacity of LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li pouch cell is 81.6 mA h, corresponding to a high energy density of 213.1 Wh kg−1. After 15 cycles at 0.1 C, a remarkable reversible capacity of 86.1 mA h and an excellent capacity retention of 98.1 % are achieved, demonstrating PI-PEO-SN CPEs can be successfully applied in large-scale commercial batteries. In addition, the steady operation of LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li pouch cells under extreme circumstances are crucially important for the practical applications of solid-state electrolytes. As described in Fig. 7 a, the open-circuit potential of LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li pouch cell is 3.455 V, which could easily light a “ZJUT” LED lamp matrix (Fig. 7b). Subsequently, LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li pouch cell is tested under bending, folding, and cutting conditions as illustrated in Fig. 7c-e. Notably, the brilliance of LED lamp matrix has no impact at all when it goes through bending and folding, which can still work normally. Even after cutting, LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li pouch cell still works stably without short circuit, and the remaining portion still could light up LED lamp matrix. These results vividly demonstrate that PI-PEO-SN has sufficient reliability and security even if it can be used in extreme conditions.

In summary, we successfully develop a facile solution casting method to ameliorate ionic conductivity, mechanical strength and interfacial stability of CPEs by introducing 3D PI frameworks and SN plasticizers. As for the practical application, LFP/PI-PEO-SN/Li coin/pouch cells exhibit high specific capacity, long cycling lifespan, superior rate capability, and excellent operational reliability even under harsh conditions of bending, folding and cutting. Although most of previous works mainly focus on the introduction of inorganic fillers into PEO-based electrolytes to improve the ionic conductivity and mechanical strength of CPEs[25,27,29], the operating temperatures of these reported CPEs often are higher than 60 °C, which is not feasible for the practical applications. In this work, to be specific, the as-prepared PI nanofibers with high aspect ratio are intertwined with each other to form 3D frameworks, which significantly enhance the mechanical strength of CPEs due to the high modulus of PI nanofibers, resulting the superior Li dendrites blocking ability. In addition, the introduced SN plasticizers serve to inhibit PEO crystallization and to increase the solubility of lithium salts, thereby promoting the ionic conductivity of CPEs and ameliorating the interfacial compatibility against with Li anode. Benefitting from the synergistic effects of PI frameworks and SN plasticizers, the obtained PI-PEO-SN CPEs exhibit a high ionic conductivity of 1.03 × 10−4 S cm−1 at room temperature with a wide electrochemical window up to 5.14 V, and a remarkable tensile strength of 4.52 MPa, as well as the satisfactory interfacial compatibility with Li anode. This work provides new insights for the design and fabrication of high energy density and high safety all-solid-state batteries.

Jun Zhang: Investigation, Visualization. Xinhui Xia: Investigation, Formal analysis. Hui Huang: Investigation, Formal analysis. Yongping Gan: Formal analysis, Visualization. Xinping He: Methodology, Data curation. Zhen Xiao: Funding acquisition, Writing – review & editing. Wenkui Zhang: Supervision, Funding acquisition, Writing – review & editing.
